title: 106_s289
content: The "Faith-Based Drug Treatment Enhancement Act" is cited as the short title. It amends Title V of the Public Health Service Act to include services provided through religious organizations for the prevention and treatment of substance abuse. This new section, Part G, specifies the applicability to designated programs. This part applies to programs providing federal financial assistance for substance abuse prevention or treatment. It excludes awards for other purposes. Definitions are provided for clarity. This part applies to federal financial assistance programs for substance abuse prevention or treatment. It does not apply to awards for other purposes. Definitions are provided for clarity, including designated award recipients and direct awards. The term 'designated award recipient' refers to an entity that has received an award under a specific program, either directly from the Federal Government (designated direct award) or through a non-Federal entity (designated subaward). The term 'designated award recipient' refers to an entity that has received an award under a specific program, either directly from the Federal Government or through a non-Federal entity. An 'award' is received directly from the Federal Government, while a 'designated subaward' is financial assistance provided through an award under a designated program by a non-Federal entity. Financial assistance includes grants, cooperative agreements, contracts, or voucherized assistance. Financial assistance provided through an award under a designated program includes grants, cooperative agreements, contracts, or voucherized assistance. Program beneficiary refers to an individual who receives program services, and program participant is defined in section 582(a)(2). Program services encompass the services provided under the program. "Voucherized assistance is financial aid provided through a designated program, including grants, cooperative agreements, contracts. Program beneficiary receives program services, and program participant is defined in section 582(a)(2). Program services include treatment for substance abuse or preventive services." "Voucherized assistance is a system of selecting and reimbursing program services where the beneficiary is given a document to pay for services." Assistance refers to a system where the beneficiary is provided with a document to pay for program services, allowing them to choose the organization that will provide services according to specified rules. The selected organization is then reimbursed by the designated award recipient. The beneficiary selects an organization to provide services based on specified rules and is reimbursed by the award recipient. The beneficiary is reimbursed by the award recipient for program services provided, or determines the allocation of program funds by selecting a service provider. SEC. 582. RELIGIOUS ORGANIZATIONS AS PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. Religious organizations have the authority to be designated award recipients, make subawards to other entities, provide program services through voucherized assistance, and be service providers under designated programs. Religious organizations can receive designated awards, make subawards, provide program services using vouchers, and be service providers under designated programs. The term 'program participant' refers to entities that have received a direct or subaward, regardless of service provision. Religious organizations can participate in designated programs by receiving awards or subawards and providing services using vouchers. They are considered program participants alongside other nonprofit providers without any discrimination. Religious organizations can participate in designated programs by providing services through voucherized assistance, on the same basis as other nonprofit providers, without compromising their religious character or the religious freedom of beneficiaries. The establishment clause of the first amendment does not require discrimination against religious organizations. Religious organizations can participate in programs without compromising their religious character or the freedom of beneficiaries. The establishment clause does not require discrimination against faith-based providers or censoring their religious expression. Religious organizations can participate in programs without discrimination or censoring their religious expression. Faith-based providers are eligible for federal programs without abandoning their religious character. Religious organizations can participate in programs without discrimination based on their religious character. They are eligible for federal programs on the same basis as any other nonprofit organization. Religious organizations participating in programs can maintain their independence and control over their religious beliefs, without being required to alter their internal governance by the Federal Government or a State. Religious organizations in programs can maintain independence and control over their religious beliefs without altering internal governance or removing religious symbols. Religious organizations participating in programs can require employees to adhere to their religious beliefs and practices, but cannot discriminate in employment based on religion. This allows organizations to maintain their independence and control over their religious symbols and beliefs. Religious organizations participating in programs can require employees to adhere to their religious beliefs and practices, but cannot discriminate in employment based on religion. Program beneficiaries have rights to object to religious organizations' requirements. Program beneficiaries have the right to object to a religious organization participating in a program. If objected, the organization must arrange for the individual to receive services through an alternative entity. If a religious organization receives a direct award, they must arrange for the individual to receive services through an alternative entity. If they received a subaward, the non-Federal entity that made the subaward will arrange for services through an alternative program participant. If a religious organization receives a direct award, they must arrange for the individual to receive services through an alternative entity. If they received a subaward, the non-Federal entity that made the subaward will arrange for services through an alternative program participant or provider. If the organization is providing services through voucherized assistance, the designated award recipient must arrange for the individual to receive program services from an alternative provider with equal monetary value. The organization must ensure that if services are provided through voucherized assistance, the individual receives program services from an alternative provider with equal monetary value, without discrimination. Religious organizations participating in programs must not discriminate against beneficiaries based on religion or belief, except when a beneficiary chooses to receive services from a different provider. Religious organizations in programs cannot discriminate against beneficiaries based on religion or belief, except when a beneficiary chooses a different provider. Program participants may require active religious participation and adherence to religious rules from beneficiaries. Religious organizations in programs must allow beneficiaries to actively participate in religious practices and follow religious rules. They are also subject to fiscal accountability regulations for federal financial assistance. Religious organizations receiving federal financial assistance must adhere to fiscal accountability regulations, including auditing principles for fund usage. If the organization keeps federal funds separate from non-federal funds, only the federal funds are subject to audit. Religious organizations receiving federal funds must comply with fiscal accountability regulations. If the organization maintains separate accounts for federal and non-federal funds, only the federal funds are audited. SEC. 583 prohibits the use of funds for sectarian worship or instruction, except when the beneficiary can choose where the assistance is used. SEC. 584 outlines the administration of programs and treatment of funds. (a) Funds provided under a designated program are aid to the beneficiary, not the organization. Program services received at the organization's facilities do not constitute federal financial assistance to the organization. (b) States cannot prohibit the use of federal funds in religious facilities or by religious organizations participating in the program. Federal funds can be used in religious facilities or by religious organizations participating in a designated program, even if state laws would prohibit the use of state or local public funds in such facilities or by such organizations. The state or local government must separate federal funds from other public funds for the program. SEC. 585 outlines educational requirements for personnel in drug treatment programs. The Congress finds that formal educational qualifications for counselors in drug treatment programs may hinder services. If a program participant imposes educational requirements, religious education must be considered. The provision of drug treatment services may be hindered by formal educational qualifications for personnel. Religious education must be considered in the delivery of program services. The State or local government must recognize the importance of religious education and training in the delivery of program services. Personnel in religious organizations should receive credit equivalent to secular course work in drug treatment or similar subjects. State or local government must give credit for religious education and training equivalent to secular coursework in drug treatment or similar subjects for personnel in organizations providing program services. State or local government program participants can set educational qualifications for personnel in organizations providing drug use reduction services, with exceptions for religious organizations. Religious organizations can be exempt from educational qualifications for personnel providing drug treatment services if they have a successful track record in drug treatment for at least 3 years. Religious organizations can be exempt from educational qualifications for personnel providing drug treatment services if they have a successful track record in drug treatment for at least 3 years and have applied for a waiver from the Secretary. Religious organizations can be exempt from educational qualifications for personnel providing drug treatment services if they have a successful track record in drug treatment for at least 3 years and have applied for a waiver from the Secretary. The State or local government must fail to demonstrate that the educational qualifications are necessary for the successful operation of a drug treatment program.
